â€œOne of the things my dad kept asking, was if I wanted some more/or something to drink or eat every time he saw an empty glass or an empty plate. He forgot I had eaten/or had my drink and asked every few minutes. I then started to leave a bit of drink in my glass, or a bit of something on the plate. That kept him thinking I was just fine and not always askingâ€ ~ Helle

â€œI worked as a Program Manager in a Memory Unit for 8 years. Hand Massages were wonderful. I used The Aroma Therapy Lotion from Bath & Body Works. It was always interesting to see how each patient responded to my touch and the scent of the lotion. If they liked the scent I would rub a small amount under their nose. That way the scent and feeling might linger for a while. Hand massages can be very relaxing and human touch is so important. Another idea I used was for the families bring in a blank photo album and pictures of individuals that their loved one knew at one time in their life. First I would go through the pictures with the patient to see if they remembered their names. When I put the pictures in the album I would include a label with the name of the person. I was looking for 2 things. 1. If the patient was still able to read and say the name and 2. If the patient remembered anything about that person. ~ Susan 

â€œNear the end, when my mom was losing the ability to swallow, I bought a tiny food processor and made â€œsnowâ€ out of water. Iâ€™d place a teaspoon of the snow in her mouth & it would quickly melt. It worked beautifully! I think you could freeze any liquids, like broth etc... freeze them into cubes & do the same.â€ ~ Carol

Hi, I'm Elizabeth Millerâ€”caregiver advocate, professional speaker, podcast host, and founder of Happy Healthy Caregiver, LLC.

Family caregiving changed my life. It taught me resilience, patience, and the importance of self-care. I cared for both of my parents while raising kids and working full-time. Now, I'm my brother's remote primary caregiver while juggling my own business (I miss the paid time off!). Tom was born with ASD and IDD. He lives in a community for those living with disabilities about an hour from me.

For almost eleven years, Iâ€™ve been on a mission to help other caregivers prioritize their own well-being while they care for others. And, I'm practicing what I preach, too!

If youâ€™re looking for tips, laughs, or someone who gets it, youâ€™ve found your corner of the internet!

ğŸŒŸ Iâ€™m the founder of Happy Healthy Caregiver, a resource hub and community for family caregivers.

ğŸ¤ I host the Happy Healthy Caregiver podcast, where I share tips and spotlight other family caregivers.

ğŸ“š Iâ€™m a bookworm who loves escaping into a good novel or personal growth book and has been a part of a book club for as long as I can remember. I share something I recently read in each podcast

ğŸŒ¸ I swear by my daily â€œmicro-self-careâ€ momentsâ€”whether itâ€™s a walk, needlepointing, or purging a cluttered space.

ğŸ¶ My happy place? Playing board games with my family while listening to one of their playlists.

ğŸŒ Travel fuels my soul, and I enjoy trying new things. I share one of the favorite things I'm loving in each episode of the podcast.

ğŸ¾ Iâ€™m a proud pet parent to an almost 15-year-old Shih Tzu and a 5-year-old Doodle, and I believe furry friends are great therapy.

Thanks for being here. Is there anyone else you know who could benefit from the content I share and this community? Maybe share this post with them.

I'm not a fan of an extensive list of resolutions that feel impossible to keep up with after a few weeks. Instead, I've been doing something the past few years that has allowed me to focus on one healthy habit a month. Habits I care about and choose. Maybe I'm adding something nutritious to my life or subtracting something that isn't.

I consider the eight categories of self-care when mapping out my monthly focus: Financial, Social, Spiritual, Intellectual, Professional, Practical, Emotional, and Physical.

You can do this at least three different ways. 

1) Decide up front what habit you'd like to focus on each month 

2) Put 12+ habit ideas in a container and draw one out each month for a bit of a surprise. 

3) Set a reminder on your smartphone to choose a new habit each month to focus on.

Learn more about this concept and get some habit ideas here: 

https://bit.ly/HHCpick12

Tom lives with disabilities (including ASD) and multiple health conditions. Last fall, we decided to keep him in Georgia full-time for more stability and better support services. Heâ€™s been living with another brother an hour away while weâ€™ve coordinated doctors, programs, paperwork, andâ€”most recentlyâ€”a residential community. Itâ€™s been productive, exhausting, and full of bumps and family conversations.

In May, I started tracking my â€œTom hoursâ€ to make invisible care labor visible. Iâ€™m at almost 140 hours since Mayâ€”about 5 hours a weekâ€”and it still feels like more.

The good news: in 2025, Tom joined a 2-day-a-week work program, and on Dec 1, he officially moved into a residential community for adults with disabilities. Itâ€™s not a perfect solution, and losing full freedom with his car is a big adjustmentâ€”but weâ€™re hopeful.

Some of you may be in the midst of a difficult care journey or perhaps have recently lost someone that you care about. I see you.

Grief can be the loss of a person or a sense of general loss. No matter the season or holiday, family caregivers are often confronted with feelings of grief.

May you honor these feelings and give yourself some grace this holiday season.

This holiday season may look different, and that's ok. Sending you holiday hugs.

Create your 20 for 2026 list!

It's an annual tradition in my family that we usually do together on New Year's Eve.

We identify up to 20 things we want to experience or try in 2026. THESE ARE NOT RESOLUTIONS!

These are tiny and FUN things we want to do in 2026 to infuse JOY.

Some of mine from this past year were:

* Lake day
* Buy myself flowers
* Enjoy a sunset
* Cook Thai Massaman at home
* Read or listen to 50 books
* Try Mahjong

Yours can be ANYTHING!

I promise that when you write it down and share it, your 2026 will be sprinkled with delight!

The added benefit of sharing this activity with your family and friends is that you can help each other check things off and maybe experience them together.

Get your FUNsheet to create your 20 for 2026 list!

3 powerful ways to become a more self-confident caregiver ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼

Sometimes, we can be bothered by a sense of imposter syndrome because we second guess ourselves or question our abilities â€¦

Here are a few of the tricks I applied when I was knee-deep in crisis mode, keeping everyone else afloat but torturing myself with self-doubt ğŸ˜£

1. Trust yourself 

Listen to your instincts and remind yourself that youâ€™ve already faced and overcome so much. Youâ€™ve aced so many things and any â€˜mistakesâ€™ have only made you stronger and wiser. Keep a list of achievements nearby to look at if you need a reminder.

2. Question your negative thinking

Ask yourself - â€œis that thought TRUE?â€ Take away their power by realising if theyâ€™re not true, why would I act on them? Write them down or say them out loud - they seem much sillier out in the open than they do in your head.

3. Visualise a great outcome

See yourself navigating the situation with confidence and allow yourself to feel proud at this imaginary scenario. Youâ€™ll trick your brain into feeling more prepared and more confident to go forward and face the real-life thing - and have a little smile in the process! 

Save this post for later and let me know if you found this helpful ğŸ’œ

My thoughts have a mind of their own! If Iâ€™m not careful they will run the whole show and before I know it, Iâ€™m watching a tragedy with a horrible ending! 

My thoughts run around without any supervision most of the time and the results are usually disastrous. 

Fear, recrimination, guilt, judgements, and second guessing take place in my head most of the time without any push back from me. 

Itâ€™s like Iâ€™m in a kindergarten class with open cans of paint all over the room and the kids are allowed to do anything they want! Stuff gets flung all over the place.

So this is a gentle reminder to myself and anyone who needs to hear it that we can at anytime pause to listen to the noise thatâ€™s happening in our heads and take control of it. 

Even for a brief moment. 

I start by actually listening to what Iâ€™m saying to myself. 

Wow. 

Thatâ€™s enough to put my hair on fire.

Then I can ask myself if what Iâ€™m saying to myself is true (usually not) then is it something that is helpful (usually not).

I then say â€œhey thanks for the feedback but thatâ€™s not really helping me right nowâ€ and think about something that brings me relief or joy or something Iâ€™ve done thatâ€™s awesome. 

Mind you, (pun) this might only get me relief for a few moments but itâ€™s worth it and offers me a rare opportunity to stop the show my thoughts are putting on. 

Itâ€™s  also training me to be aware of the circus in my head and giving me permission to put an end to it.

If our thoughts are not entertaining us we donâ€™t have to entertain them.

Let remember to get the hook, pull the plug, shut it down and lock them up. Itâ€™s like a raid on our brain. 

Go for it.

Why do we have such a hard time admitting caregiving is hard? 

That seems to be more difficult than being brave. 

We seem to be able to find the strength to carry on for others but sadly fail to make it easier on ourselves by admitting this is hard.

Iâ€™m here to tell you it is hard, and itâ€™s not reflection on us or how capable we are. 

Itâ€™s just hard. And saying that out loud or to someone we trust doesnâ€™t make us weak, it makes us miracle workers. 

Period.

Every year, at the end of the year, the pressure mounts. The Holidays need to be perfect!

They donâ€™t.

I struggle with this even today. 

I get trapped each year into this stinkin thinkin about what celebration and year end reflection should mean and be.

I want to make everything sparkle and shine and have everything perfectly magical, wonderful and special for those I love and care for. 

This undue pressure of trying to make it all perfect makes me and everyone around me miserable. 

It also wastes my time.

I donâ€™t need to make it perfect, I need to make it calm, and loving and a time to show those around me how grateful I am for them and the time we spent together this year.

The tears, the laughter, the crisis we managed, the courage we found, the love that guided us and kept us glued together. 

Finding space to celebrate those things, look around at the faces around me, and hold close the ones I have lost is the true meaning of this season. 

I donâ€™t really have to make anything happen, I just have to offer quiet time to share my heart and be truly present.

Thatâ€™s the perfect gift. 

#caregiverwarrior #caregiving #caregiver #holidays #quiet 

For more helpful info, head to my website  caregiverwarrior.com and check out my book â€œSelf Care for Caregiversâ€ to get quick, actionable ways to care for yourself available at all fine books stores!

One of the most powerful tools caregivers can have is communication. Itâ€™s helpful to remember that quiet and silence are as effective as conversation when we want to communicate. 

Communication comes in many forms and quiet is one of the most profound forms. 

I have always felt safer when Iâ€™m in verbal communication. It makes me feel seen and heard and gives me an opportunity to let others feel seen and heard as well. 

I truly love a great conversation and believe the more we let others in on how we feel the better life can be. I can chatter. Endlessly. Itâ€™s my go to way of reaching out. 

I learned something about the ways I reach out to others when I became a caregiver. 

Caregiving taught me that open communication is indeed a life saver. But it has also taught me that there are many forms of communication, and many are not  verbal. 

Yes, with the right tone and great intention, talking to someone is a wonderful way to spend time with a loved one I care for. 

There are often, however, many times when a quiet gesture or a small silence speaks volumes to someone in pain, or fear, or confusion or who is simply tired of it all. 

I can send comfort with a smile or a gentle touch or hug or just a calm, waiting silence that says Iâ€™m here, I have you, I care. 

It can almost be a relief to just be with someone without trying to fix them or the situation or filling space with words. 

I can share my energy and feeling of love simply with my presence. 

And that can speak volumes. 

#caregiverwarrior #caregiver #caregivering #quiet #selfcare

I equate parts of caregiving to gut punches. Some are smaller jabs but most of them are full out hard hits that bend us over. 

They can stop us in our track, but often we limp away without taking the time we really deserve to recover. We only pause briefly and keep moving.

I suggest we pause deeply and take a solid moment to take the weight of the punch in, give ourselves the space to say ouch really loud (cursing has been proven to be helpful) and truly acknowledge that we didnâ€™t deserve it and it really hurts. 

In that space we can also feel upset about it, frightened by it, and thrown by it. 

We are allowed to take the time to steady ourselves until the pain subsides. 

We can be gentle and kind to ourselves 

We can give ourselves credit for taking the blow with grace. 

We can be really proud of how well we handle them and how brave we are. No one takes a gut punch like a caregiver.

Once weâ€™ve taking the time we deserve to recover and reset, and allow a mini heal, we can find strength and keep moving. 

Stay bent over as long as you need. You can stand again when you are truly ready. 

For more information and useful content, please visit my website  https://www.caregiverwarrior.com
I hope you find it valuable!

Some days start out feeling hard right out of the box. A feeling of dread takes over and it can go downhill from there.

So before we get stuck in the dread and frustration, we can remind ourselves that itâ€™s just one day, not forever. 

We can do anything for 24 hours. 

And another 24 hours is a gift no matter how challenging those hours are. 

There just might be a great moment in one of those hours and if we are too wrapped up in how hard it all is, we might be looking the other way and not see that great moment. 

And even if it seems like there are no great moments and we are just slugging our way through, it will be over soon and today is a gateway to another day that might be totally different. 

Life is funny that way. Each day has its own personality. We donâ€™t have to like each one but if we have to work with them we can at least put up with them until we get to work with someone we like a lot. 

For more information and useful content, please visit my website  https://lnkd.in/dUPqppJ 
I hope you find it valuable!

This year was one for the books. Every day was a blessing. We rang in the New Year surrounded by love & our girl @_michygee family. We headed to Las Vegas for Grandmas 87th Birthday where we got to hang with so many friends like @dementiadarling & @ashley_jordan explore the city & see @rupaulsdragracelive When we got back I threw a party for Grams with all our Phoenix friends. 

In February we snuggled a lot! Grabbed dinner with our girl Rachel & saw Michelle a bunch but my favorite was Grams getting pampered at the hair salon.

In March I started hiking! It was so good for my mind & body. Spring training came to Phoenix & we got a visit from @terptoni23 And by the end of the month my sister @kacie723 came to visit for Spring Break.

By mid April we were back in the pool! We celebrated Easter with @our_generation_of_care & her beautiful family then stole her kids got a fun sleepover at our house! 

May was full of hiking & taking care of myself. Celebrating Motherâ€™s Day once again with Michelle & her family. We got to finally meet @leannspecht & started our summer road trip.

In June we got to watch my niece graduate middle school & celebrate my 38th Birthday with my family. After we did some traveling to Oklahoma where we got to meet our girl @barbie_abigailmarie & visit our caregiver friend @ciarra.holliday 

By beginning of July we were back in Phoenix roasting so we hopped right back in the car to meet my family in South Carolina, where we stayed for weeks. 

By August it was time to party again! We headed to Virginia Beach to see our girl @tashar07 & made our way to NYC where we met @cinnacatxtress & got to see my long time BfF @bethb2142 & cousin @frankiegarafola on Long Island but the fun didnâ€™t stop there because we headed to upstate New York where we had the time of our life at the Lake with @kgorman4
